questions.text: A young boy came to the OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. Which ofthe following transmits the condition described in the scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mite

Explanation:

  • The child’s symptoms of severe nocturnal itching and the presence of burrows in intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between the fingers are characteristic of scabies, which is caused by Sarcoptes scabiei (a mite).

Scabies:

  • Parasitic infection of the skin caused by Sarcoptes scabiei (itch mite).
  • Mode of spread: Scabies are highly contagious, and transmission is by skin-to-skin contact and fomites. Risk factors include poor personal hygiene.

Clinical manifestation:

  • The characteristic sign of scabies is the presence of burrows, Are thin, grayish-white or skin-colored, linear or wavy lines found in areas like the webbing between fingers, wrists, elbows, armpits, waistline, buttocks, genital area, and ankles, causing intense itching, especially at night.
  • Examination typically reveals excoriated papules, typically over the web spaces of the fingers (as shown in the image).

Other areas of the body that must be examined for lesions include:

  • The medial aspect of the wrist
  • The medial aspect of the forearm
  • Umbilicus
  • Axilla
  • Nipple
  • Genitalia/ groin- burrows (wavy, grey tunnels)

 

This distribution is called the circle of Hebra.

The face is typically spared, due to high amounts of sebum in the facial skin.

Circle of Hebra demonstrating the typical location of scabies lesions

Incorrect Options:

Louse (Option A): Lice (Pediculus humanus capitis, Pediculus humanus corporis, Pthirus pubis) cause pediculosis (head/body/pubic lice), which presents with itching and nits attached to hair shafts, not burrows in the skin.

Tick (Option B): Ticks are blood-feeding arachnids that transmit diseases like Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and babesiosis. They do not burrow into the skin or cause widespread itching.

Flea (Option D): Fleas (Pulex irritans) cause pruritic papules, often in a clustered pattern ("breakfast, lunch, and dinner" sign), but they do not form burrows in the skin.

questions.text: The involvement of which of the following results in the given condition below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lymphatics

  • The correct answer is lymphatics. Filariasis is a disease caused by parasitic worms, specifically Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori. These worms primarily inhabit the lymphatic system, causing inflammation and obstruction of lymphatic vessels. This leads to the clinical manifestations of filariasis, such as lymphedema (swelling), elephantiasis (severe swelling), and other related complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Arteries: Arteries are blood vessels that carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to various parts of the body. They do not play a direct role in filariasis. Filariasis is a parasitic infection caused by thread-like filarial worms, typically transmitted through mosquito bites. The worms primarily affect the lymphatic system, not the arteries.

Option B - Vein: Veins are blood vessels that carry deoxygenated blood back to the heart. Similar to arteries, veins do not have a direct role in filariasis. The infection mainly targets the lymphatic system, leading to the characteristic swelling of body parts due to impaired lymph flow.

Option D - DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): DVT is a condition where a blood clot forms in a deep vein, usually in the legs. While DVT involves veins, it is unrelated to filariasis. DVT results from the formation of blood clots within veins, often due to factors like prolonged immobility, certain medical conditions, or genetic predisposition.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Elephantiasis

Explanation:Elephantiasis is a condition characterized by massive swelling and thickening of the skin and underlying tissues, most commonly affecting the limbs and genitalia. It results from lymphatic obstruction, leading to chronic lymphedema and progressive fibrosis.

Elephantiasis:

  • Cause: Delayed sequel of repeated lymphangitis, obstruction, and lymphedema.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Persistent lymph leakage into tissues → chronic lymphedema → elephantiasis.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Nonpitting brawny edema (firm swelling).
    • Thickened skin, cracks, and fissures.
    • Growth of new adventitious tissue.
    • Increased risk of secondary bacterial and fungal infections.
  • Commonly Affected Areas:
    • Legs (most common), but other body parts can also be involved.

Causes of Elephantiasis:

  • Lymphatic Filariasis (most common cause)
    • Caused by parasitic nematodes like Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori
    • Transmitted by mosquito bites
    • Leads to chronic lymphatic obstruction and severe swelling
  • Non-Filarial Elephantiasis (Podoconiosis)
    • Caused by chronic exposure to volcanic soil with high silica content
    • Seen in tropical regions like Africa and South America
  • Other Causes:
    • Repeated bacterial infections (e.g., streptococcal cellulitis)
    • Tumors obstructing lymphatics
    • Milroy’s disease (congenital primary lymphedema)

Filariasis:

  • Agent:
    • Wucheria bancrofti: Lymphatic filariasis
    • Brugia malayi: Brugian/Malayan filariasis
  • Endemic areas: Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat
  • Host:
    • Definitive: Man
    • Secondary/ intermediate: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans
  • Mode of Transmission: Bite of the mosquito (vector)
    • W. bancrofti: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans (polluted water)
    • B. malayi: Mansonia (ponds, lakes)
  • Incubation period: 8-16 months.
  • Transmission: Cyclodevelopmental
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic amicrofilariae: No symptoms, smear-negative
    • Asymptomatic microfilariae: No symptoms, smear-positive
    • Acute stage (few months): Fever, lymphadenitis, epididymo-orchitis.
    • Chronic Obstructive stage (>10 years): Hydrocele, chyluria, elephantiasis
    • Occult stage: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (hypersensitivity reaction) with absent microfilariae

Syphilis (Option A):

  • Syphilis (Treponema pallidum infection) causes painless ulcers (chancre), maculopapular rash, and systemic involvement, but does not lead to massive lymphedema.

Leprosy (Option B):

  • Leprosy (Mycobacterium leprae) leads to skin lesions, nerve damage, and deformities, but does not cause gross limb swelling like elephantiasis.

Leishmaniasis (Option D):

  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with ulcerative skin lesions, while visceral leishmaniasis causes hepatosplenomegaly and fever. Neither form causes lymphatic obstruction and massive swelling.

questions.text:
Which of the following treatments are appropriate for scabies in infants?

a. 5% Permethrin cream

b. 10% Crotamitron

c. Ivermectin

d. 25% Benzyl benzoate lotion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a, b, d

Explanation:

  • Ivermectin is contraindicated in children under 5 years of age; however, all the other mentioned drugs can be safely used to treat scabies in infants.

Drugs for scabies 

Permethrin (1st line) (Option a)

A highly effective pyrethroid insecticide, with nearly 100% cure rates in scabies after a single application.

Lindane (2nd line)

A broad-spectrum insecticide, but less effective than permethrin and has a higher risk of systemic toxicity, particularly in children.

Benzyl Benzoate (2nd line) (Option d)

Minimally absorbed through the skin and has low systemic toxicity but can cause neurological symptoms in children.

Crotamiton (2nd line) (Option b)

Less prone to cause skin irritation and has low systemic toxicity but has produced lower cure rates in scabies.

Sulfur

The oldest scabicide but has several disadvantages, including messy application, unpleasant odour, and the need for repeated applications.

Dicophane (DDT)

Can be absorbed through the skin and cause systemic toxicity, rarely used due to potential side effects and safer alternatives.

Ivermectin

An oral medication that is highly effective in treating scabies.

Not to be given to children <5 yrs old, pregnant, or breastfeeding women. (Option c ruled out)

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with lymph node swelling. She has a history of toxoplasmosis infection 5 years ago and is IgG positive. What should be the next step?

choices.text: Do amniotic sampling to find if fetus is infected or not

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reassurance, continue pregnancy

Explanation:

  • Toxoplasma IgG positivity with past infection (several years ago) indicates immunity and no active infection.
  • Once infected, the risk of congenital transmission is only present during the acute phase of maternal infection.
  • Chronic/past infection does not pose a risk to the fetus and requires no intervention.
  • Therefore, reassurance and routine antenatal care are appropriate.

 

Toxoplasmosis in pregnancy

Mother

Usually asymptomatic but can transmit the disease to the infant.

Infective form

Trophozoite crosses the placenta to infect the neonate.

Risk of transplacental infection based on time of infection of the mother

Transplacental infection can occur at any time during the pregnancy, but the gestational age influences the risk of transmission.

 

As the gestational age increases, the risk of transmission increases, but the severity of neonatal disease decreases.

 

Pre-pregnancy

  • Very low chance of transmission (immunocompromised mother)
 

First trimester

  • Minimal risk of transmission.
  • If transmitted, it results in more severe fetal complications.
 

Third trimester

  • Maximum risk of transmission.
  • If transmitted, it is usually asymptomatic in newborns.

 

Diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis

Antenatal

USG

  • Done at 20-24 weeks of gestation and repeated every 2-4 weeks
  • It helps detect lesions of congenital infection, such as
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Ascites

Serology

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) or IFA (Immunofluorescence Assay) is done using maternal serum to detect IgM and IgG

PCR
  • Amniotic fluid can be used to detect Toxoplasma DNA, which can confirm the diagnosis.
  • It is not done routinely as it is invasive and expensive, and other safer options are available.

Postnatal diagnosis

Serology

Newborn Sera and maternal sera are both used to detect

  • IgG >= 1000: Possible infection
  • IgM >= 1:4 after 2 weeks of age: Indicates probable diagnosis
  • IgA: Disappears within 10 days of birth; thus, persistence indicates postnatal infection
 

Sabin-Feldman test - Complement fixation test

Other tests

  • Animal inoculation (no longer done for clinical diagnosis)
  • Skin test of Frenkel
  • Microscopy of samples to detect tachyzoites using Giemsa or PAS

 

Congenital anomalies risk is high (Option A): Risk is only high with acute infection during pregnancy, not with past resolved infection.
 

Do amniotic sampling to find if fetus is infected or not (Option C): Unnecessary since there is no evidence of recent infection; IgM would be positive in acute infection.
 

Start treatment (Option D): Antiparasitic treatment is indicated only in acute infection during pregnancy to reduce fetal risk, not in past infection.
